body:
@cart:

>  I do have thoughts on (1). From my perspective, observed_on / observed_by forces the user to think about the distinction when in 99.99% of cases they only need to care about one of the two (observed_on / "the target")

Yup. To expand on my discord thoughts: if you're asking "which observer entity is handling this event", you are likely an "internals developer" of some kind, not a normal game logic developer. We should have a nice friendly / snappy name for "the entity the event was triggered on" (ex: `trigger.entity()`, `trigger.target()`, `trigger.on()`). `trigger.entity()` is honestly my favorite. Its pretty unambiguously  "the entity this event was triggered on", and it is likely the first name normal users will look for. Iirc we invented the "target" term to appease the internals developers that considered `entity` ambiguous, but I don't think that will be true in practice.
I think that something like `.observer_entity()` is probably a good choice for the internals type. Longer, and clearly mentions that it's the observer.
Actually "target" _is_ used elsewhere as a "core" term (ex: `world.trigger_targets(event, [e1, e2])`), so using that term here does make some sense.
The `Pointer::target` storing the original "non bubbled" entity might be worth rethinking too to avoid confusion (ex: maybe that should live on Trigger, rather than on the Pointer event itself).

> Actually "target" _is_ used elsewhere as a "core" term (ex: `world.trigger_targets(event, [e1, e2])`), so using that term here does make some sense.

While true, I think `trigger_entities` works just as well.

I like:
`trigger.observer_entity()` - The Observer Entity
`trigger.origin_entity()` - Entity that was triggered by the user originally
`trigger.entity()` - Origin Entity or Entity the event has propagated to via relations

Most cases will use `entity()`, and in the cases where they need to know the `origin_entity()` it is available and can be compared against `entity()`.
`trigger_entities` doesn't cover the "component target" case (and notably that API already covers that).

Perhaps we could statically constrain it like `trigger_entities<E: Event<Target=Entity>>` and `trigger_components<E: Event<Target=Component>>`. I don't personally have an event case that would require supporting both (although I also haven't fully conceptualized what an observer-driven query cache looks like).

Either:
1. Component Targets are removed from the API and generic on the Event Types, as you suggested potentially on Discord. (Would be interested to know the extent of use of this feature, does anything use it besides Lifecycle Events ðŸ¤” )
2. Components as Entities turns them into entities, although I don't exactly know how that API would look like given that change.

I would prefer 1 long-term: I think the conceptual complexity to utility is very poor there. It feels like a design / feature that we borrowed from flecs without really having the rest of the puzzle required to have it make sense.

issue.body:
# Objective

Our various methods to get entities associated with observers can be confusing, and don't distinguish well between the common and rare cases.

- Fixes #19263.
- Fixes #17112.
- Accidentally duplicates and closes #18982. Sorry @Zeophlite!
- Related to #18710, which will need to be revisited.

## Solution

1. `On::observer` -> `On::observer_entity`
2. `On::target` -> `On::entity`
3. `Pointer::target` -> `Pointer::original_target`
4. `ObserverTrigger::target` -> `ObserverTrigger::current_target`

issue.body:
# Objective

Getting access to the original target of an entity-event is really helpful when working with bubbled / propagated events.

`bevy_picking` special-cases this, but users have requested this for all sorts of bubbled events.

The existing naming convention was also very confusing. Fixes https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/issues/17112, but also see #18982.

## Solution

1. Rename `ObserverTrigger::target` -> `current_target`.
1. Store `original_target: Option<Entity>` in `ObserverTrigger`.
1. Wire it up so this field gets set correctly.
1. Remove the `target` field on the `Pointer` events from `bevy_picking`.

Closes https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/pull/18710, which attempted the same thing. Thanks @emfax!

## Testing

I've modified an existing test to check that the entities returned during event bubbling / propagation are correct.

## Notes to reviewers

It's a little weird / sad that you can no longer access this infromation via the buffered events for `Pointer`. That said, you already couldn't access any bubbled target. We should probably remove the `BufferedEvent` form of `Pointer` to reduce confusion and overhead, but I didn't want to do so here.

Observer events can be trivially converted into buffered events (write an observer with an EventWriter), and I suspect that that is the better migration if you want the controllable timing or performance characteristics of buffered events for your specific use case.

## Future work

It would be nice to not store this data at all (and not expose any methods) if propagation was disabled. That involves more trait shuffling, and I don't think we should do it here for reviewability.

body:
> Naming: I suggested the named "listener" (to refer to the current target) and "emitter" (to refer to the original target). Note that "listener" used this way is consistent with the original bevy_eventlistener, while the term "emitter" is my own.

This worked in `bevy_eventlistener`, because `On` (the event listener) was stored on the actual entity that you want to attach the event handler for. However, in upstream Bevy, observers tend to be their own standalone entities. The *observer* is the listener, while the target is purely the entity the event was targeted at. These are typically different entities.

A listener/emitter naming scheme would also be strange for events that aren't propagated, since the "listener" and "emitter" would be the same. To me, this would kind of imply that the target emitted the event to itself. These names also have no nice connection to the event triggering API; targeted events are triggered using `trigger_targets`, which makes `target` natural, but `listener`/`emitter` has no such connection.
I can come up with other words, but I think the word "target" is really vague and not very descriptive of what's going on.

I agree that `target` is too vague. I would much prefer the terminology to be clear about which entity its referring to.

To rephrase the kinds of entity we have:
1. The original entity which was passed to `commands.trigger_targets`.
2. The entity which should currently be considered, may be the same as the above or may be different due to bubbling.
3. The entity which contains the `Observer` component.

I do think that for 2., `.entity()` is the most intuitive name people will look for. It would make sense to add a doc-alias for `target`.

for 1. and 3. i strongly prefer something explicit, like `.original_target()` (mirrors `commands.trigger_targets`) and `.observer_entity()`. In normal use these should be needed rarely enough that a short name provides too little benefit for the potential confusion.

I'm loosely in favour of splitting the `.trigger_targets()` API into `trigger_entities`/`components` - if only to make the argument type for each easier to read.
